title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 8, 2019).

The Trump administration added 28 Chinese entities to an export blacklist, citing their role in the repression of Muslim minorities, just days before high-level trade talks are set to resume in Washington.

Details that were wrong or omitted from WeWork's financial disclosures helped weaken investor appetite and will pose risks if it ever tries to go public again.

Hong Kong's stock exchange pulled a $36.6 billion bid to acquire the LSE, a deal that would have united two of the world's major trading hubs.

The NBA is resisting Beijing's pressure to punish a Houston Rockets executive who publicly supported protesters in Hong Kong.

GE said it was freezing its pension plan for about 20,000 U.S. workers and offering pension buyouts to 100,000 ex-employees.

The union for pilots at Southwest sued Boeing, alleging the plane maker rushed the 737 MAX to market and misrepresented it as safe.

Some Nissan directors will demand to see a list of around 80 Nissan employees who may have assisted Ghosn in alleged wrongdoing.

U.S. stocks slipped, weighed down by consumer-staples shares. The S&P 500 and Dow both lost 0.4%. The Nasdaq fell 0.3%.

Samsung Electronics said it expects lower third-quarter operating profit, but that the results will beat estimates.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 08, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
